question: Is regular use of aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs associated with a reduced risk of colorectal cancer in humans? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: RESULTS Regular use of aspirin and/or NSAIDs was associated with lower risk of colorectal cancer (prevalence, 28% vs 38%; odds ratio [OR], 0.69 [95% CI, 0.64-0.74]; P = 6.2 Ã— 10(-28)) compared with nonregular use.
content.source_2: Among carriers of the rs2965667-TT genotype, regular aspirin and/or NSAID use was linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer, with a higher prevalence in users than nonusers (38% vs 28%; adjusted OR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.27-1.81; P = .002), and no protective effect was observed in the rarer TA/AA genotypes.
content.source_3: After stratification by rs16973225, regular NSAID exposure did not reduce colorectal cancer risk in AA homozygotes (prevalence, 36% vs 39%; OR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.78-1.20; P = .76) and was associated with higher risk in AC/CC genotypes (prevalence, 28% vs 38%; OR, 1.54; 95% CI, 1.31-1.80).
